results.headline: Murder Most Musical
results.display_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street

results.summary_short: “Sweeney Todd” is as much a horror film as a musical. It is also something close to a masterpiece.

results.headline: Good-Time Charlie’s Foreign Affairs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Charlie Wilson's War

results.summary_short: “Charlie Wilson’s War” may be more of a hoot than any picture dealing with the bloody, protracted fight between the Soviet Army and the Afghan mujahedeen has any right to be.

results.headline: Behind the Music, This Time for Laughs
results.display_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story

results.summary_short: “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story” has a good beat and you can dance to it, though mostly you’ll probably just tap your foot.

results.headline: Racing Around the Globe, Solving a History Mystery

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of National Treasure: Book of Secrets

results.summary_short: The hyperactive sequel “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” sends its archaeologist hero on a globetrotting quest that might have been devised after a long night of Wikipedia surfing.

results.headline: Talk About Slippery Slopes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Steep

results.summary_short: “Steep” is an undeniably impressive visual spectacle that follows the sport of extreme skiing.

results.headline: P.P.S. Take Tissues to This Weepy About a Romance Tested by Death

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of P.S. I Love You

results.summary_short: “P.S. I Love You” looks squeaky clean and utterly straight. Yet as directed by Richard LaGravenese, it has a curious morbid quality.

results.headline: A Goofy Scheme to Get the Girl

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The District

results.summary_short: The Hungarian cartoon feature “The District!” is a last-minute shoo-in for the title of 2007’s most original animated film.

results.headline: Cereal as a Metaphor for Capitalism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flakes

results.summary_short: A business course on cutthroat capitalism disguised as a slacker comedy: That’s the kindest way to describe Michael Lehmann’s “Flakes.”

results.headline: Songs for a Brighter Tomorrow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Singing Revolution

results.summary_short: Can singing change history? “The Singing Revolution,” a documentary by James Tusty and Maureen Castle Tusty about Estonia’s struggle to end Soviet occupation, shows that it already has.

results.headline: Harsh Realities and Mystical Power

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Half Moon

results.summary_short: For his poetic fourth feature, “Half Moon,” Bahman Ghobadi returns to the desolation of the Kurdish borderlands and the enduring optimism of his people.

results.headline: The Folks You Meet on the Border Between Consciousness and Dreams

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Youth Without Youth

results.summary_short: “Youth Without Youth” is a narratively ambitious, visually sumptuous surrealist enterprise that tries to bend time and space together as neatly as the folds in an origami swan.

results.headline: Out of Warhol’s Inner Circle Into the Void

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Walk into the Sea

results.summary_short: “A Walk Into the Sea” is Esther B. Robinson’s documentary about Danny Williams, a former Harvard student who was a part of Andy Warhol’s Factory scene.

results.headline: Now You See Me

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Look

results.summary_short: “Look,” an unsettling, rudely funny but not entirely credible feature by the writer and director Adam Rifkin, is an ensemble narrative for the age of public surveillance.

results.headline: Man About Town, and Very Alone

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Legend

results.summary_short: In spite of its third-act collapse into obviousness and sentimentality, “I Am Legend” is among Will Smith’s better movies.

results.headline: From Memories, There’s No Escape

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kite Runner

results.summary_short: In both novel and film form, “The Kite Runner” recounts a simple yet shrewd story about that favorite American pastime: self-improvement.

results.headline: Familiar Faces With a Digital Makeover

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alvin and the Chipmunks

results.summary_short: Hollywood continues its tired milking of old television properties with “Alvin and the Chipmunks,” a slick updating of the musical-cartoon franchise.

results.headline: Teachers United

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arranged

results.summary_short: In “Arranged” two devout Brooklyn schoolteachers clutch hands across the religious divide as their respective families prepare to marry them off.

results.headline: For a Single Mother, Mr. Claus Is Mr. Right

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perfect Holiday

results.summary_short: “The Perfect Holiday,” directed by Lance Rivera, is that most dispiriting product, a formulaic movie that doesn’t believe in itself.

results.headline: Giving Testimony on the Horror That Was Nanking

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nanking

results.summary_short: “Nanking” is a swift, incisive documentary about one of the lesser-known horrors of the 20th century.

results.headline: Strangers in a Land That’s Not So Strange

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Band's Visit

results.summary_short: “The Band’s Visit,” the first feature by the Israeli writer and director Eran Kolirin, flirts recklessly with obviousness, cuteness too.
